+0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"d529099db0d8b4219157f2582cdb0479","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn56@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-01-802_ca24e60cc28dd84a.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":60137,"destBytes":37310,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn56@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-01-802_ca24e60cc28dd84a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-19-244_f1d65a984093a065.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn39@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-22-269_2c4c0e4c3db643a1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn83@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-18-048_c7a6d586dd628f95.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn85@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-25-168_5cf41aabcc10bfac.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn91@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-24-039_156ccbd56dde3729.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn21@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-24-089_6b8a3a1d07b04921.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn72@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-19-438_ba8c39ff75215326.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-9.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn76@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-26-902_04b7980156edc3ef.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-10.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn38@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-29-136_f4741a9ec6f582fc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-11.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn38@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-18-128_9cf7df7e914424a7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-12.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn39@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-20-808_c78f7091f956a28e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-13.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-13.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Do-Office-Yoga-Step-14.jpg/aid2398731-v4-728px-Do-Office-Yoga-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn48@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-19-188_0ae8734945c5c983.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380856},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Cook Irish Oatmeal","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Cooking Irish oatmeal is pretty similar to cooking your favorite type of rolled oats, with the main difference being that they take a little bit longer to cook. Just like rolled old-fashioned or quick oats, you can enjoy Irish oatmeal with all kinds of delicious toppings. In case you didn’t know, Irish oatmeal is just another name for steel-cut oats, so you can prepare either type of oats in the same way. Whip up a batch of Irish oatmeal for breakfast or whenever you want a tasty, warm, and nutritious bowl of porridge! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Stovetop Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stovetop-Irish-Oatmeal\">Stovetop Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>3-4 cups (750-1000 mL) of water</li> \n  <li>1 cup (90 g) of Irish oatmeal or steel-cut oats</li> \n  <li>1/8 tsp (0.75 g) or less of salt</li>\n </ul> \n <p><i>Makes 4-6 servings</i> </p> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Slow Cooker Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Slow-Cooker-Irish-Oatmeal\">Slow Cooker Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>3.5 cups (875 mL) of water</li> \n  <li>1 cup (90 g) of Irish oatmeal or steel-cut oats</li> \n  <li>1 cup (118 g) of peeled and chopped apple</li> \n  <li>1/2 cup (79.5 g) of raisins</li> \n  <li>2 tbsp (28.4 g) of butter</li> \n  <li>1 tbsp (7.91 g) of cinnamon</li> \n  <li>2 tbsp (27.5 g) of brown sugar</li> \n  <li>of vanilla extract</li>\n </ul> \n <p><i>Makes 6 servings</i> </p> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Microwave Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Microwave-Irish-Oatmeal\">Microwave Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>2 cups (473 mL) of water</li> \n  <li>1/2 cup (45 g) of Irish oatmeal or steel-cut oats</li>\n </ul> \n <p><i>Makes 1 serving</i> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Stovetop Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stovetop-Irish-Oatmeal_2\">Stovetop Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Bring 3-4 cups (750-1000 mL) of water to a boil in a pot on your stove. Use 3 cups (750 mL) of water if you prefer your oatmeal more firm or 4 cups (1000 mL) of water if you like it creamier. Pour the water into a pot and bring it to a boil over high heat on one of your stove’s burners.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-1.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also substitute milk for some or all of the water if you want even creamier oatmeal.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir 1 cup (90 g) of Irish oatmeal and a pinch of salt into the water. Measure out the oats first and dump them into the boiling water. Grab a pinch of salt and toss it in, then stir everything together thoroughly using a large spoon or another type of stirring utensil.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A pinch of salt is usually considered to be a little less than 1/8 tsp (0.75 g) of salt. Use no more than 1/8 tsp (0.75 g) of salt if you prefer to measure it out instead of eyeballing it.</li> \n    <li>You can use steel-cut oats instead of Irish oatmeal. They are the same thing.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Reduce the heat to low once the water starts to boil again. Keep an eye on the pot to make sure the mixture doesn’t boil over. Turn your burner’s heat down to low as soon as the oats start boiling.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This usually only takes a few seconds, so you won’t have to stand there waiting for too long.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Simmer the oats, stirring occasionally, for 20-30 minutes. Keep an eye on the oats to make sure they stay simmering and use your spoon or stirring utensil to stir them around and scrape the oats off the bottom of the pot every so often. Carefully give the oatmeal a taste test after 20 minutes and keep simmering it until it gets as creamy as you like, but not longer than 30 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might have to play with the heat on your stove to get the oatmeal to simmer perfectly.</li> \n    <li>If you see steam rising off the pot and a couple of bubbles in the oatmeal every few seconds, it’s simmering at a good level.</li> \n    <li>Overcooking Irish oatmeal can ruin its nutty flavor, so don’t go over 30 minutes.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Serve the oatmeal in individual bowls. Remove the oatmeal from heat. Transfer a scoop or two of oatmeal to each serving bowl using a spoon.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-5.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also just get out a bowl for everyone you’re serving and divide the oatmeal evenly among them or let each person serve themselves the amount they want.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Store any leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 1 week. Scoop any oatmeal you don’t eat right away into a sealable container and put the lid on. Place the container in your refrigerator and eat it within 1 week.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-6.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you want to reheat the oatmeal, just stir in a splash of milk or water to help it soften up.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Slow Cooker Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Slow-Cooker-Irish-Oatmeal_2\">Slow Cooker Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Put 3.5 cups (875 mL) of water and 1 cup (90 g) of Irish oats in a slow cooker. Measure out the oats and water in whatever order you want. Pour them into the slow cooker’s pot.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can use steel-cut oats instead of Irish oatmeal to make this recipe. They are the same kind of oats.</li> \n    <li>Don’t attempt to make any other type of oats in a slow cooker. They will cook too fast and turn out mushy.</li> \n    <li>Keep in mind that this recipe takes up to 8 hours to finish cooking. If you want to eat the oatmeal for breakfast, prepare this a night ahead of time.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir in 2 tbsp (27.5 g) of brown sugar and 1 tbsp (7.91 g) of cinnamon. Measure out the cinnamon and sugar in any order and dump them into the slow cooker with the oatmeal and water. Stir the mixture until the sugar dissolves to sweeten it evenly.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Feel free to adjust the amounts of these ingredients to suit your tastes or omit any that you don’t like.</li> \n    <li>You could cut the sugar in half if you want your oatmeal to be less sweet or use 1/4 of the cinnamon if you want less cinnamon flavor, for example.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mix in of vanilla extract and 2 tbsp (28.4 g) of butter. Measure out and pour in these ingredients in any order. Give the mixture a quick stir to distribute the vanilla extract.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t like vanilla flavor, you can skip the vanilla extract.</li> \n    <li>The butter adds to the creaminess of the oatmeal, but you can skip it if you’re on a low-fat diet.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add 1 cup (118 g) of peeled and chopped apple and 1/2 cup (79.5 g) of raisins. Peel and cut an apple into small cubes and measure out about 1 cup (118 g) of the apple into the slow cooker. Measure out 1/2 cup (79.5 g) of raisins and toss those in as well, then give everything a good stir to evenly distribute the ingredients.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It’s fine if you want to leave out the apples, the raisins, or both. You’re the one eating the oatmeal, so make it however you most enjoy it!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cover the slow cooker and turn it on to low heat for 6-8 hours. Cook the oats for 6-7 hours if you like firmer oatmeal. Let them cook for 8 hours if you want softer, more creamy oatmeal.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-11.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can start taste testing the oatmeal after the first 6 hours pass to see how you like the texture and flavor. Keep cooking it until it reaches the consistency you like.</li> \n    <li>You can also cook the oatmeal using the “warm” setting on your slow cooker if your slow cooker tends to run a little hot or if you know you’re going to leave it for longer than 8 hours. Just taste it after 8 hours or so to see how creamy it is and keep it warming until it has the consistency you want.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Serve the oatmeal in bowls. Turn off your slow cooker, remove the lid, and stir the oatmeal. Put a scoop or two in a bowl and let it cool slightly while you prepare your toppings.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-12.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You could warm up the serving bowls for a few seconds in your microwave if you want the oatmeal to stay nice and warm while you enjoy it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep leftover oatmeal for up to 1 week in a sealed container in the fridge. Transfer any of the oatmeal that you have left over into an airtight container and seal it up. Put the container in your refrigerator and enjoy it within 1 week.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-13.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Stir in a splash of milk or water when you reheat the oatmeal to help it loosen up.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Microwave Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Microwave-Irish-Oatmeal_2\">Microwave Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Put 1/2 cup (45 g) of Irish oatmeal into an 8 cup (2000 mL) bowl. Measure out the oats and pour them into a microwaveable bowl with a capacity of about 8 cups (2000 mL). The oatmeal bubbles and expands in the microwave, so a large bowl gives it plenty of room to do this without spilling over the sides.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can substitute the same amount of steel-cut oats for Irish oatmeal because they are the same thing.</li> \n    <li>Microwaving oatmeal is a good method if you’re just making a personal serving. However, if you want to make Irish oatmeal for more people, it’s better to do it on the stovetop or in a slow cooker because you can make more servings at once.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add 2 cups (473 mL) of water to the bowl and stir the water and oats together. Measure out the water and pour it into the bowl on top of the oats. Use a spoon to stir the oats and water together.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Stirring the oats and water together before they go in the microwave helps the oatmeal cook evenly.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Microwave the oatmeal on high for 10 minutes, stirring once halfway through. Place the bowl with the oats in the microwave and make sure it’s set to high power. Set the cook time for 10 minutes and start the microwave. Stop the microwave and give the oatmeal a good stir after the first 5 minutes, then start it up again and let the oatmeal finish cooking.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can set the microwave for 5 minutes, stir, then set it for the remaining 5 minutes if it’s easier for you to keep track of time this way.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Transfer the oatmeal to a serving bowl. Take the oatmeal out of your microwave carefully using an oven mitt or gloves. Use your spoon to scoop it out into a smaller serving bowl.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-17.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This recipe only makes about 1 serving, so there probably aren’t going to be any leftovers to save!</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Sweeteners, Add-ins, and Toppings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Sweeteners,-Add-ins,-and-Toppings\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sweeteners.2C-Add-ins.2C-and-Toppings\">Sweeteners, Add-ins, and Toppings</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Sweeten Irish oatmeal with brown sugar or honey to taste. Sprinkle brown sugar on top for a classic oatmeal sweetener. Drizzle honey over your bowl of oatmeal for a healthier sweetening option.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Feel free to skip the sweetener if you prefer or if you’re on a low-sugar diet.</li> \n    <li>Try using maple syrup as a sweetener.</li> \n    <li>If you're following a sugar-free diet, an artificial sweetener like stevia is a good choice.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir in a pat of butter or a splash of cream for extra creaminess. Slice a small square of butter off a stick of butter and put it in the middle of the bowl so it melts into the oatmeal. Squeeze a splash of cream over the oatmeal in addition to or instead of the butter to suit your tastes.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-19.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These additions are completely optional. You can customize your oatmeal any way you want!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add classic dry toppings like cinnamon and nuts as you please. Try sprinkling 1/4 tsp (0.66 g) of cinnamon on top and stirring it into your oatmeal if you want to add a classic spice flavor. Top it all off with about 1 tbsp (9.37 g) of any kind of nut you like to add some crunchy texture and nutty flavor<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Toppings and serving amounts are just ideas and suggestions. Feel free to experiment with other spices and ingredients if you prefer.</li> \n    <li>You can use another type of warm spice like ground cloves or nutmeg or another type of sliced fruit like an apple instead. Try different combinations until you find your favorite way to enjoy Irish oatmeal!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try sweet and juicy fruit toppings like berries and sliced bananas. Top each serving with a handful of any berries you like for added natural sweetness and nutrition. Slice up a banana and put about 1/2 a banana’s worth of slices in each serving bowl as well for more healthy fruit.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-21.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Irish Oatmeal Step 21.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-21.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-21.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It’s totally up to you what toppings and how much of them to use. You can use only berries or only banana slices or adjust the amounts of each to suit your personal preferences.</li> \n    <li>You can also try mashing a banana instead of slicing it to use as a topping.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>A bowl of oatmeal is basically like a blank canvas for toppings. Go ahead and try any toppings you think you might like and don’t feel limited to what you read about here!</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don’t try to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Oatmeal\" title=\"Make Oatmeal\">make regular oatmeal</a> using an Irish oatmeal recipe. The cook times for rolled oats are much shorter, so you’ll end up with a mushy mess if you do this.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Stovetop Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stovetop-Irish-Oatmeal_3\">Stovetop Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Pot</li> \n  <li>Measuring cup</li> \n  <li>Spoon or other stirring utensil</li> \n  <li>Serving bowls</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14\" title=\"Edit section: Slow Cooker Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Slow-Cooker-Irish-Oatmeal_3\">Slow Cooker Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Slow cooker</li> \n  <li>Measuring cup</li> \n  <li>Spoon or other stirring utensil</li> \n  <li>Serving bowls</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Irish-Oatmeal&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15\" title=\"Edit section: Microwave Irish Oatmeal\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Microwave-Irish-Oatmeal_3\">Microwave Irish Oatmeal</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Bowl with 8 cup (2000 mL) capacity</li> \n  <li>Microwave</li> \n  <li>Measuring cups</li> \n  <li>Spoon</li> \n  <li>Serving bowls</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span .webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-19.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-26-019_5b65727daadcde7b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-21.jpg/aid12153198-v4-728px-Cook-Irish-Oatmeal-Step-21.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn96@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-476_f3b836d99b4430a3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380801},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Make a Bird Box","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Bird watching is a relaxing, fulfilling activity that’s easy for most people to do. You can bring the birds to your own backyard by building them a bird box, or a variation of a bird house. Once you have your materials, you can spend a single afternoon building a cozy home for the birds in your area so they have a safe place to nest during breeding season. The best thing about bird boxes is that they’re reusable, so you can clean them up and use them time and time again! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Cutting the Lumber\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cutting-the-Lumber\">Cutting the Lumber</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Measure and cut 2 side panels out of untreated wood. Use pine, cedar, or plywood that’s thick. Using a tape measure and a ruler, measure out the 2 side panels, then use a saw to cut them out. Cut out 2 panels that are both wide and in length on one side and in length on the other.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The side panels will be slanted at the top to create the classic bird box shape.</li> \n    <li>To find untreated lumber, look for wood that’s been approved by the Forest Stewardship Council, or the FSC, by looking for the FSC logo on the label.</li> \n    <li>Since all your pieces are the same width, it may help to start out with a piece of lumber that’s wide.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut out the front, base, roof, and back from the same wood. Using the same wood, grab a tape measure and measure out 4 new pieces. Then, use a saw to cut them out. The measurements for each piece are:<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The front piece: wide and long.</li> \n    <li>The base piece: wide and long.</li> \n    <li>The roof piece: wide and long.</li> \n    <li>The back piece: wide and long.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Carve out a diameter hole in the front panel. Attach a spade bit, or a boring bit, to your drill and make a pencil mark about 1/3 of the way down your front panel. Use the boring bit on your drill to carve out a wide hole in the front so that birds can enter the box.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This hole might seem small, but it will allow smaller birds to get into the box while keeping large predatory birds out.</li> \n    <li>If you want to attract larger birds, leave the front panel off of the box completely to make it more accessible.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drill 5 small holes in the base piece. Using your same boring bit, make 5 marks spaced evenly along the base piece. Then, use your boring bit to make five wide holes to let water and waste flow out of the box.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These drainage / ventilation holes will keep the box cleaner so the birds are more likely to stay for long periods of time. It will also ensure that the birds have enough air to breathe while they’re in the box.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Assembling the Box\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Assembling-the-Box\">Assembling the Box</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Nail the sides to the bottom of the back plate. Start by lining up your side pieces so that the flat edges are flush with the bottom of the back plate and the tops of the side pieces are slanted downwards. Use 2 nails on either side to attach the side pieces to the sides of the back plate, leaving about of space at the top of the back plate.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Leaving the space at the top will give you room to attach the roof.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach the base to the back plate so it’s flush with the sides. Grab your base plate with the holes in it and line it up with the bottom of the back plate and the bottom of the side pieces. Use 4 nails to hammer the base piece into place to the back plate and the side pieces.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The base piece needs to be really secure since that’s what the birds will actually be sitting on in the box.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Line up the front panel with the sides, then use nails to attach it. Grab the front piece and situate it on the side panels so that the hole in the front is near the top of the box. Use 3 nails on either side of the front piece to attach it to the side panels, then use 2 more nails to attach the front piece to the base piece.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Attach a rubber hinge to the roof and the base. Grab a strip of rubber that’s wide and tall. Use 2 nails to attach the top of the strip to the top of the back plate. Then, attach the top of the roof to the edge of the rubber hinge with 2 more nails.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The roof should rest on the top of the 2 side panels to stay closed.</li> \n    <li>Attaching the roof with a hinge rather than nails will make it easier to clean and maintain the box over time.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Paint or decorate the box if you’d like to. If you want to decorate your bird box, you can grab a paint brush and use non-toxic, water-based paint to use on the outside of the box. Let the box dry completely for about 1 day before you hang it up outside.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Painting the box can make it easier to see, and it might make it a cute attraction in your yard.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Hanging and Cleaning the Box\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Hanging-and-Cleaning-the-Box\">Hanging and Cleaning the Box</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Set up your bird box between February and March. If you’re in the southern part of the country, put up your box no later than the end of February. If you’re in the northern part of the country, put it up before late March.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Bird-Box-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Bird Box Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Make-a-Bird-Box-Step-10.jpg/aid100918-v4-728px-Make-a-Bird-Box-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This will give the birds in your area ample time to use the box during breeding season.</li> \n    <li>It can take a few years for birds to find your box, so don’t be discouraged if it doesn’t get used right away.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drill a hole in the back plate for hanging. Use a drill bit to make a hole at the top of the back plate. This will make it much easier to hang the box later on so the screw doesn’t have as much wood to push through.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You may have to push through the rubber hinge a little bit, which is fine.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mount the box at least above the ground. Choose a tree or a pole in your yard that’s out of the direct sunlight to hang your bird box. Grab a screw and use your drill to attach the top of the bird box to the tree or the pole. Make sure it’s really sturdy so that the birds can go in and out with ease.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Putting the bird box high up will keep the birds safe from predators on the ground.</li> \n    <li>You don’t need to add in any nesting materials to your box, because the birds will bring in their own.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wash your bird box every October or November. After each breeding season, take your box down from its mount and dump out any nesting material or waste inside of it. Use boiling water to clean out and disinfect the inside, then let it air dry before you hang it back up again.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Never use harsh chemicals to clean out your bird box, or you could harm the birds.</li> \n    <li>If you open up the box and find unhatched eggs, leave them in the box. According to wildlife laws, the eggs can only be removed from October to January and they must be destroyed – it is illegal to keep the eggs.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>When birds start using your bird box, try to keep your distance so they don’t get spooked.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Many species of birds are very territorial and won’t nest in boxes if they’re too close together.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Box#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>thick and long pine, cedar, or plywood</li> \n  <li>Saw</li> \n  <li>Measuring tape</li> \n  <li>Pencil</li> \n  <li>Drill</li> \n  <li>Boring or spade bit</li> \n  <li>drill bit</li> \n  <li>Nails</li> \n  <li>Hammer</li> \n  <li>Screw</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Popcorn-Balls-for-Birds\" title=\"Make Popcorn Balls for Birds\">Make Popcorn Balls for Birds</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Bird-Watch\" title=\"Bird Watch\">Bird Watch</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Take-Care-of-a-Parakeet\" title=\"Take Care of a Parakeet\">Take Care of a Parakeet</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Birdcage\" title=\"Clean a Birdcage\">Clean a Birdcage</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bird-Nest\" title=\"Make a Bird Nest\">Make a Bird Nest</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Bird-Box&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 03 Oct 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Make-a-Bird-Box-Step-10.jpg/aid100918-v4-728px-Make-a-Bird-Box-Step-10.jpg","linkMd5":"01c8cd58d6635fa6d2aff6a0a87a47da","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn15@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-783_3142287fd7e5f27c.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":100421,"destBytes":73740,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Make-a-Bird-Box-Step-10.jpg/aid100918-v4-728px-Make-a-Bird-Box-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn15@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-783_3142287fd7e5f27c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380825},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Kool-Aid is a fun, cheap, and easy way to temporarily dye the ends of your hair! Start by grabbing 2-3 packages of Kool-Aid in the color of your choice. Mix the powder with water and bring the mixture to a boil on your stovetop. After about 1 minute, remove the mixture from the heat and transfer it to a heat-safe bowl. Lower the ends of your hair into the dye bath for 15-25 minutes to achieve your new color! Your results should last anywhere from a few days to a few weeks. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Choosing a Color and Prepping Your Hair\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Choosing-a-Color-and-Prepping-Your-Hair\">Choosing a Color and Prepping Your Hair</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Select 2-3 packages of Kool-Aid in the color of your choice. If you have blonde hair, you probably only need 2 packages of Kool-Aid. If your hair is darker than that, go with 3 packages. You can choose any color you want! Red, blue, and purple are popular options that show up nicely on all hair colors. You can also mix your own custom colors!<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, try mixing together 2 packages of grape Kool-Aid and 1 package of cherry to get a high-intensity burgundy color.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If you have dark hair, avoid using yellow or orange. You can try green, but you’ll probably get better results with a more saturated hue, like purple or blue.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put on an old T-shirt and plastic gloves to prevent stains. Kool-Aid will definitely stain anything it comes in contact with! Put on an old T-shirt and cover your workspace with newspaper or plastic garbage bags to prevent staining. It’s also a good idea to wear plastic gloves to protect your skin.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Place several old towels within reach on your work surface. You will need to squeeze the excess dye out of your hair as soon as you pull it out of the dye bath, so make sure you have several old towels within reach and ready to go! Otherwise, you risk dripping the potent Kool-Aid dye all over the floor or counter.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep in mind that the Kool-Aid will permanently stain the towels, so use old ones.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Brush out your dry hair until it’s tangle-free. Kool-Aid dye works best on freshly washed, completely dry hair. If your hair is damp, let it air-dry or blow-dry it before you try to dip-dye it. Use a wide-toothed comb to carefully remove any tangles, starting at the ends of your hair and working your way up to the roots.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It will still work if you haven’t washed your hair recently, but it’s important that your hair is dry so that it will soak up the color effectively.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put your hair in pigtails or a low ponytail. You don’t have to do this, but it makes the process much easier, especially if your hair is long. Use an elastic to put thick hair into 2 loose pigtails and let them hang over the front of your shoulders. If your hair isn’t that thick, a low, loose ponytail will be fine. If there’s any hair that you don’t want to dip-dye, go ahead and clip it up and out of the way.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you just want to dip-dye the underside your hair, pull the top half up and secure it with a clip.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Dipping Your Hair in Kool-Aid Dye\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Dipping-Your-Hair-in-Kool-Aid-Dye\">Dipping Your Hair in Kool-Aid Dye</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pour all of the Kool-Aid powder into a large pot or saucepan. Open all of your Kool-Aid packages and dump them into a big pot or saucepan. Choose a pot that can easily accommodate the length of your hair! Then, place the pot on a burner on your stovetop.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Add about of water to the pot. There is no exact amount of water for this. The less water you use, the more vibrant your results will be. If you want sheer results, use more water. It’s also important to use enough water to accommodate for the length of hair you want to dip. If you aren’t sure how much water you should use, try about .<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you want to dip-dye the last several inches of your hair, you should add enough water to the pot to accommodate that depth.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Boil the mixture over medium-high heat for 1 minute. As the mixture heats up, stir it with a wooden or metal spoon so that the Kool-Aid dissolves completely. Once the water is boiling, keep your eye on a timer or clock. The mixture only needs to boil for about 60 seconds before it’s ready to use.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep in mind that this will probably stain your wooden spoon permanently!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Transfer the liquid to a heat-resistant bowl or cup. Turn off the stove burner and carefully pour the hot dye bath mixture into a bowl or cup. Be very careful doing this because the water is extremely hot and can definitely burn you. If your hair is in pigtails, it might be easier to use 2 separate bowls.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the pot handle feels hot to the touch, use an oven mitt to pick it up.</li> \n    <li>If you’re using 2 separate bowls, be sure to pour an equal amount of dye bath into each one.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lower the tips of your hair into the dye bath to your desired depth. Sit at a table and put the bowl or bowls of dye in front of you. Then, position your hair into the dye bath up to the length you’d like. Keep in mind that the dye will creep up your hair about , so take that into consideration when choosing your depth.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Be sure to keep your face out of any steam that you see rising from the bowl.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Let your hair sit in the dye bath for 15-25 minutes. 15 minutes should be enough for light brown hair. If you’re blonde, you may only need to soak for about 5 minutes. If you have dark hair, 20-25 minutes is probably more realistic. The timing also depends on the level of color saturation you want to achieve. The longer your hair sits in the water, the more vibrant your results will be.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep an eye on the clock or set a timer in case you lose track of time.</li> \n    <li>Try not to move around too much while your hair soaks. If your hair shifts around in the dye bath, your results might not look even.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Setting the Color\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Setting-the-Color\">Setting the Color</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pull your ends out of the water and squeeze the excess dye out with towels. Once the allotted time is up, grab the old towels you put to the side earlier and squeeze the ends of your hair with them. Keep squeezing until all of the excess moisture is removed from your hair. Your hair should be damp and not dripping at all at this point.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Blow-dry your hair as your normally would. Grab a paddle brush and your hair dryer and blow-dry your hair until it’s completely dry. The heat from the blow dryer will set the color, so don’t skip this step. It’s also important to dry your hair completely.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a3/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-13.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Whenever your hair is damp, it will bleed color onto the clothes you’re wearing and your pillows.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Run a straight iron over your locks to set the color even more. You don’t have to do this, but it will definitely help you lock in the color a little more. Work in small sections and pull the straight iron through your hair quickly. Then, you can go ahead and style your hair as you normally would.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-14.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have curly hair, you can definitely skip this part.</li> \n    <li>Be sure to wipe off the straight iron’s plates with a thick towel or oven mitt to get rid of any dye residue.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Limit how often you shampoo your hair to extend the results. Kool-Aid is a temporary dye. Depending on your hair color and texture, your color could last anywhere from a few days to a few weeks. The color will naturally fade a little more every time you shampoo it, so limit how often you wash your hair to prolong your results.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-15.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can use a shower cap to protect your hair from water when you’re in the shower or bath.</li> \n    <li>Swimming will also cause the color to fade faster. Any time you wet your hair, the color will fade a little more.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use clarifying shampoo or baking soda to remove the color. Washing your hair several times with a clarifying shampoo should fade it. Depending on how bright your results are, you may need to take more extreme measures. Boil a pot of water on the stove and stir in 2 tablespoons (30 grams) of baking soda. Then, just dip your hair into the water for 30 seconds. The color will start coming off immediately! You may need to dip it a few times to remove the color completely.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-16.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Shampoo your hair as you normally would once the color is gone to rinse out the baking soda.</li> \n    <li>Be sure to deep condition your hair thoroughly, since stripping the color will dry out the ends.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>2-3 packages of Kool-Aid</li> \n  <li>Large pot or saucepan</li> \n  <li>1-2 heat-safe bowls</li> \n  <li>Spoon</li> \n  <li>Several cups of water</li> \n  <li>Old T-shirt</li> \n  <li>Plastic gloves</li> \n  <li>Several old towels</li> \n  <li>Hair dryer</li> \n  <li>Straight iron (optional)</li> \n  <li>Clarifying shampoo or baking soda (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-Temporarily\" title=\"Dip Dye Hair Temporarily\">Dip Dye Hair Temporarily</a></li> \n  <li><a class=\"mw-selflink selflink\">Dip Dye Hair with Kool Aid</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Your-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-at-Different-Lengths-with-Different-Colors\" title=\"Dip Dye Your Hair with Kool Aid at Different Lengths with Different Colors\">Dip Dye Your Hair with Kool Aid at Different Lengths with Different Colors</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UlwwNGi2Zng&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=46\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UlwwNGi2Zng&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=46</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a
