</ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 30 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"1cfd2e9e6a4f00c21b52797d8e816c3d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn38@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-839_670a1a38b1c3fb34.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":77093,"destBytes":53998,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn38@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-839_670a1a38b1c3fb34.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn14@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-18-079_3dd1326740640c59.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn39@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-27-172_a2b1c1bc063b331b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-22-547_a12b39760c05d144.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn58@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-345_5e622b06e92e7c08.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn63@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-27-400_1429dd65d50437ab.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn39@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-24-719_ee2ac070866d6de8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn59@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-19-254_de9720158e9d5df6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn17@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-24-611_e9dea055e0668c61.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn42@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-25-524_c3357d5a8c6d1a3a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn40@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-23-337_5f6fd118ab0743f3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn43@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-20-211_24530a059a66ddf9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a3/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-13.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn49@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-29-106_1cd2d38b3f2397a9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-14.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn71@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-20-431_031bffacfeff0bab.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-15.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn44@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-22-486_eb2d4b81045a82e2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-16.jpg/aid2660427-v4-728px-Dip-Dye-Hair-with-Kool-Aid-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn33@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-898_ef9980c23da4794a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380901},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Carry Cargo on a Bike","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Whether you want to carry a change of clothes for bicycle commuting, camping gear for touring, or a whole load of groceries from the warehouse store, you can do it on a bike. There are a whole range of options to choose from to carry cargo on a bike. From cargo racks with panniers to baskets and different types of bags, you’re sure to find a method that works for you. There are also a variety of specially-built cargo bikes you can purchase to suit your cargo-carrying needs. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Installing a Cargo Rack\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Installing-a-Cargo-Rack\">Installing a Cargo Rack</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Select a rear-mounted cargo rack on your bike for a high cargo capacity. A rear-mounted cargo rack is a rack that you install on your bike above the back wheel. You will be able to strap cargo directly to it, attach panniers (bags specifically made for bike cargo racks), or put a crate on the rack to hold cargo.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-1.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you are just going to mount one rack, then a rear-mounted rack is the most versatile option with the most cargo capacity.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add a front-mounted cargo rack on your bike for additional cargo capacity. Front-mounted racks go above your front wheel and are smaller than rear-mounted racks. Strap items to them directly, put smaller panniers on them, or use them as supports for baskets or handlebar bags.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-2.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t need a lot of cargo capacity, you can also use a front-mounted rack on its own, instead of in addition to a rear-mounted rack.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a cargo net, rack straps, or bungee cords to secure items to the rack. A cargo net is a stretchy net with hooks on the corners designed to hold items in place on a bike cargo rack. Rack straps are similar, but are just individual straps instead of a net. Bungee cords also work when you wrap them around items tightly and hook the ends to the rack.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-3.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is the most inexpensive way to carry cargo on a cargo rack. A cargo net or rack strap will cost you about $5 USD, and bungee cords can be even cheaper.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mount panniers to the sides of the bike rack for a modern, versatile option. Panniers are bags designed specifically to mount to the sides of a bike cargo rack. They are easy to attach and detach from the rack with clips, straps, or hooks so you can bring them anywhere with you.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-4.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Panniers are usually sold in pairs (one for each side of the rack) and can range in price from about $50-$300+ USD.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Using Bags, Baskets, Straps, or a Trailer\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Using-Bags,-Baskets,-Straps,-or-a-Trailer\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-Bags.2C-Baskets.2C-Straps.2C-or-a-Trailer\">Using Bags, Baskets, Straps, or a Trailer</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Wear a backpack or messenger bag to carry small loads. A basic backpack is sufficient to carry light loads of items on your bike. A messenger bag hangs to one side and leaves your back uncovered, which may help you stay cooler if you're riding on a hot day.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-5.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Bike and outdoor supply stores often sell backpacks and messenger bags that are designed with bikers in mind for a more comfortable ride.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach a basket, box, or crate to your bike for a functional vintage look. There are a variety of baskets available that attach to the front of your handlebars or the sides of a cargo rack for when you just want to throw a couple things in. Another option is screwing or otherwise securing a box or crate to a cargo rack for larger loads.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-6.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Baskets are easy to remove when you don’t need them, whereas a crate or box that is secured to your cargo rack will be a little more difficult.</li> \n    <li>Keep in mind that carrying items in an open container will mean they are not protected from the rain. A waterproof bag or cover will solve this problem.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use handlebar bags or saddlebags to carry small essential items. There are a wide variety of smaller bags designed to attach to your bike in front of the handlebars, onto the frame, or under the seat. These bags are good for holding stuff you want to carry with you while biking, such as repair kits, tools, or personal items like your phone and wallet.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-7.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can find all kinds of smaller accessory bags at a bike shop or outdoor supply store to customize your bike for carrying different cargo.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Secure things to the frame of your bike with straps or bungee cords. Use frame straps, rubber straps, or bungee cords to secure cargo to the frame of your bike. Make sure that the straps don’t wrap around and interfere with any of the mechanics of your bike, such as brake lines.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-8.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Frame straps are velcro straps specifically made for securing things to your bike frame. Rubber straps, like the kind used for binding skis, as well as rubber or regular bungee cords also work.</li> \n    <li>The spot where the seat tube meets the down tube and the spot between the down tube and the top tube (near the head tube) work well for securing items to your bike with this method.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Get a bike trailer to carry large amounts of cargo. There are trailers of all shapes and sizes that are designed to attach to the back of bikes to carry bigger loads. Get a trailer that either clips to your seat post or to the rear dropout.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-9.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Trailers are a good option if you want to keep your bike light and free of cargo most of the time, but want to be able to carry heavy loads once in a while.</li> \n    <li>Bike trailers can often carry or more and come in waterproof models or even models designed to carry specific cargo.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Getting a Special Cargo Bike\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-a-Special-Cargo-Bike\">Getting a Special Cargo Bike</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Get a longtail cargo bike to have lots of modification options. Longtail bikes have an extended rear rack that can be modified with large panniers, crates, boxes, or even extra seats. Choose a longtail cargo bike if you want to be able to adapt it to suit a variety of cargo-carrying needs.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-10.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Longtail cargo bikes often come with open-topped panniers, nets to secure cargo to the top, and optional handles or backrests.</li> \n    <li>A longtail cargo bike will cost you anywhere from $1000-$2000+ USD.</li> \n    <li>Keep in mind these types of cargo bikes are larger and harder to maneuver than regular bikes or some other types of cargo bikes.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Purchase a utility bike for a sturdy, easy-to-ride cargo bike. A utility bike is a standard bike but built with a heavier frame so it is able to support more weight. They’re easier to ride and maneuver than larger cargo bikes, while still being able to carry big loads.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-11.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Utility bikes also commonly have metal baskets or racks built onto their frames for out-of-the-box cargo-carrying capacity.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Choose a cycle truck to carry a box of cargo in front of the handlebars. Cycle trucks are about the same size and shape as a normal bike, but with a smaller front wheel. They have a built-in box or a platform in front of the handlebars for carrying cargo.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-12.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These are a good option when you want a cargo bike that is not too large or heavy, but still has room to carry cargo in front when you need to.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Buy a box bike to carry large loads in front of the bike. Box bikes have a long wheel base at the front and a smaller front wheel. There is a boxy or flat cargo area in between the handlebars and the front wheel that sits low to the ground.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/22/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-13.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Box bikes are a good choice to carry deliveries around a city, such as grocery deliveries. They can even be used to create bicycle food carts.</li> \n    <li>Box bikes can get quite expensive, and cost from about $2500-$6000 USD.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Get a cargo tricycle or cycle rickshaw for added stability. These are similar to box bikes, but with a third wheel at either the front or the back. They offer more stability and balance for carrying heavy loads at the front of the bike, but are harder to maneuver around corners.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Carry Cargo on a Bike Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-14.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can get fancier cargo tricycles that tilt when you go around corners so that they have closer to the same maneuverability as a normal bike.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Bring an insulated bag or cooler to keep cold foods cold if you’re going grocery shopping. It can go in a pannier or basket.</li> \n  <li>Any cargo increases your total weight. If you're trying to ride far or fast, or planning to do a lot of climbing, then keep your load as light as possible.</li> \n  <li>Consult the employees at a bike shop for help selecting the right equipment and installing it correctly if you aren’t sure how to do it yourself.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Make sure no straps, corners of bags, or other loose ends will interfere with your wheel, pedals, gears, or brakes.</li> \n  <li>Always fasten your load securely. Use bungee cords or straps to secure things in place.</li> \n  <li>Verify that you can balance and control your bike with whatever load you carry or attach before riding in traffic. Swinging or shifting loads can unbalance a bike, and heavy loads extending behind the seat or rear axle can cause the bike to fishtail.</li> \n  <li>If you are riding at night, make sure none of your lights are obscured by your cargo. You can get lights that attach to your cargo racks to make them more visible.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bicycle-Saddle-Bag\" title=\"Make a Bicycle Saddle Bag\">Make a Bicycle Saddle Bag</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Build-a-Bicycle-Cargo-Trailer\" title=\"Build a Bicycle Cargo Trailer\">Build a Bicycle Cargo Trailer</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hang-a-Bike-on-the-Wall\" title=\"Hang a Bike on the Wall\">Hang a Bike on the Wall</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Replace-Bicycle-Trailer-Bearings\" title=\"Replace Bicycle Trailer Bearings\">Replace Bicycle Trailer Bearings</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 09 Oct 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-1.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"c10f1bd57921f58aae21b756471cb1da","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn5@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-777_b4f774cf43d50757.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":74690,"destBytes":51884,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-1.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn5@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-777_b4f774cf43d50757.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-2.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn27@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-21-719_f5af9b0dfea4b06c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-3.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn52@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-115_dfc2330ce3ae2513.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-4.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn37@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-095_75422269d30c6d8e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-5.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn91@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-22-819_a4e0bcbb5321f0b6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-6.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn92@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-20-507_add7d375ff51484b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-7.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn63@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-19-379_c869f971392904e6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-8.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn100@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-18-017_cbbd0aa78f8bf128.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-9.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn16@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-28-121_2dfb5fac2262a5ee.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-10.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn26@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-27-980_4f1e11f7f8847045.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-11.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-18-088_2f238777287e6b81.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-12.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn47@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-25-627_ac7f2088cced97c8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/22/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-13.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn5@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-25-248_5209bd8b160e7a50.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-14.jpg/aid6581665-v4-728px-Carry-Cargo-on-a-Bike-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-27-640_f8c027fbba014d10.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380917},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Display Embroidery Hoops","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Embroidery hoop art involves a lot of effort and creativity, so you should put your hard work on display! Unlike other types of creative hobbies, hand embroidery designs are easy to display within their hoops, and don’t need a lot of bells and whistles, like glass, to be admired. Before you can put your hoop on display, you first need to “finish” the embroidery, or tuck all the extra fabric within the hoop so your project looks really polished and nice. Once you’ve done this, you have a whole array of display options to choose from! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Finishing the Hoop\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Finishing-the-Hoop\">Finishing the Hoop</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Lay your project face-down on your work surface. Find a clean, flat area where you can finish up your embroidery project. Flip your project over, so the actual embroidery is face-down while the back of the wooden embroidery hoop is face-up.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-1.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Sew a loose running stitch along the outside of the hoop. Thread a needle with a length of embroidery thread. Focusing on the excess fabric, weave the thread in and out of the fabric to create a line of loose stitches going around the outside of the hoop. At the beginning and end of this stitched loop, you’ll have 2 extra “tails” thread dangling from the bottom of your embroidery project.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-2.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This stitching should look like a big circle.</li> \n    <li>You don’t need to do any fancy stitching for this—very simple stitches will suffice.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut the extra fabric off the wooden hoop so there’s only left. Snip off the excess fabric from around your hoop, leaving about margin of fabric outside of your stitching. Toss out any of the leftover fabric that you’ve trimmed away from the hoop.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-3.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Tug on the loose thread tails to pull the stitched fabric into the hoop. Grab both sections of leftover thread that are sticking out along the bottom of the hoop. Pull on them firmly, which will cause the leftover fabric to tighten and be pulled into the hoop itself. Continue tugging on these threads until the fabric cannot tighten anymore.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-4.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The fabric will look ruffled once it’s pulled into the hoop.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Tie the loose threads together in a single knot to secure the fabric. Knot the leftover tails that you just used to pull in the extra fabric. Once they’re tied, leave them in the center of the embroidery hoop.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-5.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Trace and cut out a circular piece of fabric to cover the back. Place a piece of wool or felt on top of your embroidery hoop. Trace along the circular edge with a fabric marker, then cut out the circle.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f8/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-6.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You’ll be using this to “back” your embroidery hoop, so it’ll be ready to go on display.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Glue the trimmed fabric down so it stays in place. Place a few dots of hot glue beneath the fabric ruffles, so they stay put behind the embroidery hoop. Wait several seconds for the glue to dry before you move your hoop around anywhere.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-7.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Secure the felt circle to the back with glue. Drizzle a ring of hot glue along the perimeter of your fabric circle. Lightly press this felt onto the back of the hoop, which will cover the leftover fabric. Give the glue several seconds to dry completely before you display the hoop.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-8.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also stitch this circle to the back of your hoop, but this may take a bit more time.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Hanging Wall Displays\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Hanging-Wall-Displays\">Hanging Wall Displays</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Attach a hanging loop near the screw on top of the hoop. Drape a loop of string along the top screw of your embroidery hoop. Hang this loop over any type of nail or wall hook, so you can display your embroidery wherever you’d like. To hide the screw and hanging loop, glue a nice bow to the top of your hoop as an extra decoration.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-9.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Try using mounting blocks for a nail-free solution. Grab a pack of mounting blocks, or small squares with a sticky adhesive that go directly on your wall. Stick 2 mounting blocks on top of one another to create a really thick “hook,” then drape the top of the hoop over the mounting block.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-10.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This will work best if your hoop doesn’t have a fabric backing on it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hang up your embroidery hoop in a custom frame. Search online for specialty frames designed specifically for embroidery hoops, or other related products. Arrange and secure your hoop in this frame before placing it on the wall.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-11.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>These types of frames are pretty inexpensive. You can find them on different crafting websites, like Etsy.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Display your embroidery hoops in a group on a gallery wall. If you create a lot of embroidery designs, it might be worth displaying them in a group together! Look for an area in your home where you have a lot of open wall space, and display your hoops there! You don’t need a special design or pattern in mind as you hang them up—all of your hoops together will create a really fresh, eclectic look.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-12.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Creative Display Options\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creative-Display-Options\">Creative Display Options</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Prop your hoop on a shelf as a simple decoration. Embroidery hoops have a lot of structure on their own, and don’t need a lot of bells and whistles to be put on display. Look for any open areas on a bookshelf, hutch, or mantel, and see if you can prop your hoop up there.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-13.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, you can prop up an embroidery hoop on a piece of furniture in your dining room as a simple decoration.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drape the hoop over a doorknob. Attach a hanging loop or other type of sting to the top screw on your embroidery hoop. Place this hoop over your doorknob, so you can keep it on display in a subtle, creative way.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-14.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Place your hoop on a small craft easel as a cute display option. Visit your local craft store and pick up a tiny, decorative wooden easel. Keep this easel on a shelf, or another piece of furniture where it can be displayed prominently.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-15.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Display your small hoops as Christmas tree ornaments. If you made an embroidery design on a small hoop, think about repurposing it as a Christmas ornament! Attach an ornament hanger to the top screw along your embroidery hoop, then dangle it from a tree branch.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Display Embroidery Hoops Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-16.jpg/aid12184695-v4-728px-Display-Embroidery-Hoops-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can always cater your future embroidery designs to a holiday theme if you plan on doing this.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Finishing the Hoop\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Finishing-the-Hoop_2\">Finishing the Hoop</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Embroidery thread</li> \n  <li>Sewing needle</li> \n  <li>Fabric scissors</li> \n  <li>Hot glue gun</li> \n  <li>Hot glue sticks</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Different Display Options\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Different-Display-Options\">Different Display Options</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Bow (optional)</li> \n  <li>Hanging loop (optional)</li> \n  <li>Mounting squares (optional)</li> \n  <li>Custom frame (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Spruce up the side of your hoop with some fun ribbon, or other small decorations!<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Display-Embroidery-Hoops#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Display-Embroidery-Hoops&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span
