+0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-10-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"e4079b9f22b5c8b01494718fc6e82e1f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn12@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-01-908_6794759eae835b9c.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":49952,"destBytes":33284,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn12@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-01-908_6794759eae835b9c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-7.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn11@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-26-992_77e9afa126e7e223.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-3.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn92@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-28-079_e27b2f700ad2e106.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn34@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-26-859_210ac7ec76e025f4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-25-766_c45411a81dd1ac66.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn22@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-18-032_fc053e46bb5063cf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn69@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-24-954_cacf7cbeeaf28e87.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn56@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-18-025_2edb0ebced828e19.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn84@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-22-170_c3eafaff213da366.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn4@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-23-726_55e56eb007e12d8f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-8.jpg/aid5964934-v4-728px-Make-a-Gratitude-List-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn100@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-20-694_3e84d17545fa14dc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380916},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Study a Week Before an Exam","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>You're ready to ace your upcoming exam, but first you have to study. If there's only a week until your exam, you might be feeling stressed out and not sure where to start. Fortunately, a week can be enough time to get ready for a test. Just study a little every day so you can keep your stress levels low. You might even have fun while you study! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Creating Time and Space for Studying\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-Time-and-Space-for-Studying\">Creating Time and Space for Studying</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Schedule 1 to 2 hours of study sessions into each day of the week. Finding time to study can be super hard, but it’ll be easier if you plan ahead. Go over your schedule for the week and identify pockets of time you can use for studying. You don't have to do it all at one time, so it's okay to schedule several short study sessions. Mark these times in your agenda or calendar so you won’t forget.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 1 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can use a paper agenda or your phone’s calendar.</li> \n    <li>Try to study for at least 1 hour every day so you can really learn and memorize the material. You may want to study longer than that each day if you need more time to review the material.</li> \n    <li>If you have the same daily schedule, you might plan your study sessions for the same time, like every day from 4:00 to 5:30 p.m. You could also split up the sessions, such as 6:00 to 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 to 5:45 p.m.</li> \n    <li>If your schedule varies, plan around your daily events. You might study on Monday from 8:00 to 9:30 p.m., Tuesday from 3:00 to 3:30 p.m. and 7:00 to 7:45 p.m., Wednesday from 6:00 to 7:15 p.m., etc.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Organize your class materials so it’s easy to pull them out. You don’t want to waste any of your study time looking for stuff. Keep your textbook, notes from class, and notes you’ve taken outside of class together. Additionally, keep pens, pencils, highlighters, and a notebook handy.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you always study in the same spot, such as a desk in your bedroom, keep your study materials in this area.</li> \n    <li>If you like to study on the go, keep your materials together in your book bag.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pick a quiet, comfortable place to study. You don’t need a special spot to study. All you need is a quiet place with a table where you can spread out your materials. Identify a place where you feel comfortable studying before your study session starts. Additionally, ask people around you to not disturb you.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>At home, you might study at a desk in your bedroom or at the kitchen table.</li> \n    <li>You could also try a coffee house, the library, or even a picnic table outside.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove distractions from your study space. It’s super easy to get distracted, so do your best to remove potential distractions. Start by decluttering the space so you have a clear spot to study. Then, turn off your TV and silence your phone so you won’t be tempted by them. If you’re not using your computer to study, turn it off, as well.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you use your computer to study or feel tempted by your phone, use apps and websites that temporarily block your access to social media. For example, try Offtime, BreakFree, Flipd, Moment, or AppDetox.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> This way you won’t be tempted to give into distraction while you’re studying.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Don’t try to cram at the last minute. You’re probably super busy, so you may feel like you don’t have time to study. However, waiting until the night before your test will set you up for failure. It’s really hard to memorize a lot of information in a short period of time, so study a little each day over the week before the test so you have time to learn the material.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You probably know people who brag about cramming for tests, but don’t take their word for it. Just do what’s best for you.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Reviewing Your Coursework\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reviewing-Your-Coursework\">Reviewing Your Coursework</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Examine the review sheet if your teacher provided one. A review sheet will typically cover all of the information that’ll be on the test, so use it to your advantage. Go over the sheet to see what material you need to learn. Reference your review sheet before each study session to check your progress.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your teacher provides a list of terms or information you need to memorize, use the review sheet to create flash cards.</li> \n    <li>Your review sheet might include example test questions. If so, use your text and notes to answer the questions.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Read important texts aloud to help you remember them. Reading aloud may help deepen your understanding of the text. Go back over your text to review areas you highlighted in your first reading or passages you didn’t understand. Read these parts of the text aloud to help you process them.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Do this while you’re studying at home or somewhere you can be alone.</li> \n    <li>If you have a study group, you could all take turns reading the passages aloud.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Write-a-Summary\" title=\"Write a Summary\">Summarize</a> your readings to help you identify the main concepts. Chances are, your test will cover the key concepts you learned about a topic. Fortunately, writing summaries helps you find these key concepts so you know what to study. After you read a section of text, summarize it in your own words in your notes.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might write something like, “Each governmental body has separate powers, and they can all check each others’ powers. This allows for checks and balances.”</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Expand on your notes and past assignments to create a study guide. Create a personalized study guide early in the week so you can use it during later study sessions. Start by rewriting your notes. As you do this, expand on them and fill in any gaps using your text and online resources, if you need them. Then, add questions and answers from your review sheet and past class assignments.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Type up your study guide if that’s easier for you. You might also try handwriting the study guide with different colored pens.</li> \n    <li>You could also get questions from your textbook. Often, there are questions at the end of a reading or chapter.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Flash-Cards\" title=\"Make Flash Cards\">Make flashcards</a> to help you memorize information. Flashcards are super helpful for studying things like vocabulary, facts, and processes. Create your own flashcards using index cards or cut squares of paper. Write a term, question, or date on 1 side, then write the answer on the other. You can also print out pre-made flashcards from online.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Carry your flashcards with you during the week before the test. This way you can pull them out and shuffle through them when you have a few spare moments.</li> \n    <li>You can find pre-made flashcards on the website Quizlet.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Checking Your Knowledge\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Checking-Your-Knowledge\">Checking Your Knowledge</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Do a practice test a few days before the exam to check your progress. Taking practice tests helps you check your mastery of the content and identify areas you still need to study. Treat your practice test like the real thing. Time yourself, rely only on your own knowledge, and do your best. After you grade the practice test, spend extra time studying material you struggled with.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use your past quizzes and assignments to create your own practice test.</li> \n    <li>If your instructor has released past copies of the test, use them as practice tests.</li> \n    <li>You can also look up the topic online with the words “practice test” to get a sample exam.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Ask someone to quiz you over the material to test your knowledge. Sometimes it’s helpful to have someone else check your understanding of the content. Give your review sheet, study guide, and flashcards to a friend or family member. Have them randomly ask you questions about the material, then do your best to answer them.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you get an answer wrong, write down the question so you can go back over the material again before the test.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Start a study group so you can learn from each other. Studying with friends can be both fun and beneficial. Invite your friends to a group study session at the library, a coffee shop, or your home. Share your notes and try to learn from each other.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might plan to meet once or twice during the week before the test. For example, you might schedule a group study session the Saturday before the test.</li> \n    <li>Take turns teaching each other the material. This will deepen everyone’s understanding of the course work.</li> \n    <li>Go over each person’s notes to see if there are things that some of you missed. This can provide a more in-depth review of class discussions.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Review online tutorials if you’re struggling with the material. Don’t worry if you’re having trouble understanding your course material because you still have time to learn it. Take advantage of academic resources online. Watch video tutorials and read free study guides to help increase your knowledge.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try the Khan Academy for free tutorials. You can also check YouTube and sites like Sparknotes.</li> \n    <li>If your school offers free tutoring, attend the sessions offered during the week before your test to get help with the material.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Making Studying More Fun\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Studying-More-Fun\">Making Studying More Fun</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Take a 10 to 15 minute break every hour so you don’t get mental fatigue. You probably want to maximize your study time, so you may feel guilty about taking breaks. However, breaks will actually help you stay more focused during your study sessions. Plan to take at least a 10-minute break each hour you study.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you might study for 45 minutes, then take a 15-minute break. Come back and study for another 45 minutes.</li> \n    <li>Similarly, you might study for 30 minutes, take a 10-minute break, and then study for another 30 minutes.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Be active during your study breaks to boost your energy. Get up and move around during your study breaks. Even a short burst of exercise can get your blood pumping, which can help you focus better. Try going for a short walk, dancing to your favorite songs, or doing calisthenics.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 16 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, you might do some jumping jacks, push ups, and squats.</li> \n    <li>If you have a dog, consider taking it for a walk.</li> \n    <li>Create a short 10-to-15 minute playlist of upbeat songs if you want to dance.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Snack on healthy foods to help you stay focused. Eating snacks while you study can help you enjoy your study sessions more. However, pick the right snacks so your brain is performing at its best. Here are some great options for study snacks:<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 17 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Fruit, like apple slices, grapes, or orange slices</li> \n    <li>Nuts</li> \n    <li>Popcorn</li> \n    <li>Greek yogurt</li> \n    <li>Veggies and dip, like carrots and hummus or broccoli and ranch dressing</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Listen to music so studying is more fun. Studying can feel like a chore, but listening to music may help. Music can relax you and might help you enjoy studying, at least a little bit. In general, listening to instrumental, classical, or music with nature sounds is best while studying. However, it’s okay to listen to whatever music helps you concentrate.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Study a Week Before an Exam Step 18 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Create a playlist for your study sessions with songs that inspire you.</li> \n    <li>Songs with lyrics can be distracting. If this is a problem for you, look for instrumental songs in your favorite genre. You can easily find pop, rock, hip hop, and experimental songs that don’t have lyrics.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Spread out your study sessions so you can do a little bit at a time. This can help you manage stress before test day.</li> \n  <li>Talk to your teacher if you’re having trouble understanding the material. They may offer to tutor you before or after school.</li> \n  <li>Studying with a friend might make it more fun! Just make sure your study group stays on task.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don’t wait until the night before a test to start studying. You likely won’t be able to retain much of what you study, and you’ll probably stress yourself out. Instead, study a little at a time over the entire week before your test.</li> \n  <li>Distractions can quickly derail your studies. Avoid the temptation to turn on the TV, check your phone, or play video games during your breaks and especially while you’re studying.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Pass-an-Exam\" title=\"Pass an Exam\">Pass an Exam</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Pass-Any-School-Test-in-Middle-School\" title=\"Pass Any School Test in Middle School\">Pass Any School Test in Middle School</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Offer-Encouragement-to-Someone-Who-Has-Failed-an-Exam-or-Test\" title=\"Offer Encouragement to Someone Who Has Failed an Exam or Test\">Offer Encouragement to Someone Who Has Failed an Exam or Test</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Calm-During-a-Test\" title=\"Stay Calm During a Test\">Stay Calm During a Test</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-1-Version-4.jpg","linkMd5":"cb24eb39cd96926a52d40b34c981caca","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn39@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-01-773_83bf7ab4ecf046fc.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":91367,"destBytes":51500,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-1-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn39@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-01-773_83bf7ab4ecf046fc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn64@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-17-975_2af2ee9d49b783ff.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn33@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-25-451_1a744483030d4ecd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn63@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-21-125_6818061e58ada99e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn73@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-24-310_02dbfd9a0febe749.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn31@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-20-116_190ee8ba82dc386a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn13@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-24-627_f56c0da45ef275f9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn72@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-18-083_2ff9a42b42a53532.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn49@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-24-403_f5824e738c967ab9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn26@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-24-016_487f0cb1291ff26f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn55@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-25-695_8db6f87154059e4b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn79@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-24-385_2029505f9bdecd3e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn21@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-26-306_7af50233cfced808.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn79@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-23-645_a1af04ece334cb87.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn22@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-17-993_c59dd7d9c50083a8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-16-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn15@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-22-454_7accc13305072e7b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn99@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-27-757_d8163086ac2e8be0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid1231051-v4-728px-Study-a-Week-Before-an-Exam-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380929},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Improve Your Hearing","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Hearing loss can be scary thing for some, and people experience it all the time. Luckily, there are many ways you can improve your own hearing or protect yourself from damage. If you’re already experiencing hearing loss, then see your doctor to talk about the variety of options to fix the problem. You can also prevent your hearing from getting damaged in the first place. A few simple tricks in your everyday life can maintain your hearing for years to come. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Medical Treatments\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Medical-Treatments\">Medical Treatments</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Visit a doctor if you’ve noticed difficulty hearing. If hearing loss is interfering with your everyday life, then it’s time to see your doctor. Make an appointment and let the doctor examine your ears to determine what’s causing it and find the right solutions.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The exam will probably include an inspection of your ears and a simple hearing test. Some doctors have specialized equipment that can do a more thorough test of your eardrums.</li> \n    <li>The doctor may refer you to an ear specialist (otolaryngologist) or audiologist for further testing. This can pin down exactly what’s causing your hear loss and how to fix it.</li> \n    <li>While you need an exam for any hearing loss, a sudden loss of hearing, particularly in one ear, could be a serious medical problem. Don’t hesitate to see your doctor in this case.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Let your doctor remove built-up earwax if your ear canal is blocked. In some cases, hearing loss is from a simple blockage caused by earwax. Your doctor will spot this right away when they examine your ears. Luckily, it’s a very easy fix. The doctor will remove the earwax with a small tool or vacuum. Once your ear canal is cleared, your hearing should improve.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The doctor might also send you home with ear drops that will dissolve wax buildup. Use these exactly how your doctor tells you to.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Don’t try to dig earwax out yourself at home. You could damage your eardrum and make the hearing loss permanent.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a hearing aid if your inner ear is damaged. Hearing loss from damage or old age isn’t reversible naturally. Luckily, there are devices that can help you regain your hearing. The most common is a hearing aid. This small device fits into your ear and amplifies sound so you can hear better. It might not fully restore your hearing, but it can make your everyday life much easier.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>There are several types of hearing aids, ranging from types that rest in your ear opening to larger types that wrap around your ear. There are also more powerful bone-anchored hearing aids. Your doctor will counsel you on the best type for you.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>There are also over-the-counter hearing aids that might help with mild hearing loss. These won’t work as well as prescription types and aren’t widely available yet, but they might work for you. Talk with your doctor about the benefits of these devices.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider getting a cochlear implant if hearing aids don’t help. Sometimes, your inner ear is damaged enough that sound can’t reach your auditory nerve. This is tough to deal with, but there's good news. Cochlear implants help people with this problem all the time. This device bypasses your ear canal and brings sound directly to the auditory nerve.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> A surgeon will install the implant with a minor surgical procedure, and it should improve your hearing if the auditory nerve is healthy.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The outer part of a cochlear implant is removable like a hearing aid, so you can put it on and take it off.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup> You cannot remove the internal part of the implant, however.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Have minor surgery to correct abnormalities in your ear canal. In some cases, the bones or structures in your ear don’t form properly, causing hearing loss. A minor surgical procedure could correct this issue and improve your hearing. An ear specialist will counsel you on whether or not you need surgery and talk you through the process.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You may also need surgery if you have persistent ear infections. Fluid might not be draining properly from your ear.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Tell your doctor if you experience hearing loss after taking medication. Some medications, known as ototoxic medicines, could potentially cause hearing loss. Over 200 medications could fall into this category, and there’s no reliable way to determine who will experience this side effect. The best thing to do is monitor your hearing and tell your doctor immediately if you notice any problems after taking medication.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Some medications that can cause temporary hearing loss include salicylate pain relievers like aspirin, quinine, and some diuretics.</li> \n    <li>Other medications could cause permanent damage if you take them long enough. These include some antibiotics like gentamicin and chemotherapy drugs.</li> \n    <li>Hearing loss is much more common if you take high doses or multiple types of ototoxic medicines at the same time. Always take your medication as directed to reduce the chance.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Natural Hearing Improvement\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Natural-Hearing-Improvement\">Natural Hearing Improvement</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Try sound location exercises to sharpen your hearing. You might be able to maintain or improve your hearing with practice. Have someone hide an item that makes a repetitive sound, like an alarm. Then make the environment noisy, like by turning on the TV. Try to lock on to the sound and follow it to find the object. Doing this repeatedly can improve your ability to focus on specific sounds.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For a similar hearing exercise, try listening to someone read out loud in a noisy environment. Block out the distracting noise and try to focus solely on the reading.</li> \n    <li>If you already have hearing loss, then sound location exercises probably won’t help. You need a medical exam and possibly hearing aids to fix this.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Follow a healthy diet to support your ear health. Like any other body part, your ears need proper nutrition to work properly. In particular, getting enough zinc, potassium, folic acid, magnesium, vitamin D, and omega-3s help reduce inflammation in your ear canal and prevent damage to your hearing. You can get all of these nutrients from a healthy, balanced diet.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Some of the healthiest foods to eat are leafy green vegetables, bananas, nuts and seeds, fish, poultry, and low-fat dairy products.</li> \n    <li>You can also take dietary supplements if you aren’t getting enough nutrients from your daily diet. Talk to your doctor before you start using any supplements to make sure they’re right for you.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Exercise regularly to maintain your hearing. There is actually a connection between aerobic exercise and hearing health. As long as your ears haven’t been damaged, then regular exercise can help sharpen your hearing and maintain it into old age. For the best results, get 20-30 minutes of aerobic exercise at least 5 days per week.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e4/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Aerobic exercises are activities like get your heart rate up, like running, biking, swimming, or kickboxing classes. You could also just take a daily walk.</li> \n    <li>Resistance exercises like weight training are also good for your health, but they aren’t connected with improved hearing. For those benefits, you’ll need aerobic exercise.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Reduce stress to keep your mind clear. It’s possible that stress and anxiety can impact your hearing.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup> If you regularly feel stressed, then take some steps to relax and de-stress. A clearer mind could improve your hearing.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try some relaxation exercises like meditation, yoga, or deep breathing. Even a few minutes a day could make a big difference.</li> \n    <li>Doing activities you enjoy is also a great stress-reducer. Try to make time for your hobbies so you feel less overwhelmed.</li> \n    <li>Remember that this won’t actually fix any damage in your ears, so you may still want hearing aids if you’ve been exposed to loud noises.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try herbal supplements for tinnitus. Tinnitus is a constant ringing or buzzing in your ear that's usually an early stage of hearing loss. There's little evidence that natural remedies can make a big difference, but some herbal treatments could help. If you experience tinnitus, try some of these supplements after asking your doctor if they're safe for you.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Ginkgo biloba.</li> \n    <li>Zinc.</li> \n    <li>Vitamin B.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Protecting Your Ears\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Protecting-Your-Ears\">Protecting Your Ears</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Avoid loud environments as much as you can. Being around loud noises is one of the main causes for hearing loss. As much as you can, stay out of very loud environments and noisy situations. This can help maintain your hearing and prevent damage.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Generally, if you’re trying to talk with someone and you have to yell to hear each other, then the environment is too loud.</li> \n    <li>Sounds over 85 decibels, or roughly as loud as a motorcycle engine, can be harmful to your hearing. You can download smartphone apps to measure the current decibel levels and see if the environment is too loud.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wear ear protection whenever you’re around loud noises. You can’t always avoid loud noises, especially if it’s part of your job. In these cases, always wear ear protection to prevent damage.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup> Earplugs are handy and will work in most situations, but protective earmuffs block even more sound and are good for very loud noises.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is especially important if you’re using power tools or work around heavy equipment. Over long periods of time, these devices can cause major damage.</li> \n    <li>This is also important for bartenders or people who work at concert venues. The music in these places is usually very loud.</li> \n    <li>Keep earplugs with you for unexpected loud situations. This way, you’ll always be ready to protect your ears.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep the volume down when you’re using headphones. Headphones focus music right onto your eardrums, so they pose a high chance for causing hearing loss. Keep the volume under control to prevent any hearing loss.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you often have to turn the volume up to hear your music over other sounds, then try using noise-canceling headphones.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Avoid sticking things into your ears. Any objects in your ears could damage your eardrum and cause hearing loss. Don’t stick cotton swabs, tweezers, or your fingers into your ears.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your ears clean themselves, so you don’t need to dig wax out with a cotton swab.</li> \n    <li>If you do have something stuck in your ear, go to the doctor or emergency room right away instead of trying to get it out yourself.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Quit smoking to prevent damage in your ears. There’s evidence that smoking could damage your hearing by reducing blood flow to your ears. If you smoke, then quit as soon as possible, and avoid starting in the first place if you don’t.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Improve Your Hearing Step 16 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid7596-v4-728px-Improve-Your-Hearing-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Secondhand smoke is also harmful and could cause similar damage. Avoid smoky environments and don’t let anyone smoke in your home.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Ringing in your ears, also called tinnitus, is a sign of inner ear damage and can be a precursor to hearing loss.</li> \n  <li>If you go to a loud concert or show, give your ears a break for a few days afterward and avoid loud noises. This can help you avoid further damage.</li> \n  <li>Hearing aids and cochlear implants are totally optional. Don't feel you need to wear them if you don't want to.</li> \n  <li>Hearing loss isn't a tragedy. You can still <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Live-a-Happy-Life-if-You-Are-Deaf\" title=\"Live a Happy Life if You Are Deaf\">live a happy life</a> with hearing loss.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Become-an-Interpreter-for-the-Deaf-and-Hard-of-Hearing\" title=\"Become an Interpreter for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing\">Become an Interpreter for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Doorbell-for-Deaf-Person\" title=\"Make a Doorbell for Deaf Person\">Make a Doorbell for Deaf Person</a></li> \n \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Unclog-the-Inner-Ear-or-Eustachian-Tube\" title=\"Unclog the Inner Ear or Eustachian Tube\">Unclog the Inner Ear or Eustachian Tube</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Improve-Your-Hearing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hearing-loss/symptoms-causes/syc-20373072\">https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hearing-loss/symptoms-causes/syc-20373072</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hearing-loss/symptoms-causes/syc-20373072\">https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hearing-loss/symptoms-causes/syc-20373072</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_ref-17\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer <li id=\"_note-19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Improve-Your-Hearing#_ref-19\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\"
