er-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-13.jpg/aid12170837-v4-728px-Get-Your-Significant-Other-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn61@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-25-019_63e6611ab21fe238.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Get-Your-Significant-Other-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-14.jpg/aid12170837-v4-728px-Get-Your-Significant-Other-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn76@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-19-056_2438370306df1fad.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Get-Your-Significant-Other-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-15.jpg/aid12170837-v4-728px-Get-Your-Significant-Other-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-20-680_eb8153b47c8427c3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Get-Your-Significant-Other-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-16.jpg/aid12170837-v4-728px-Get-Your-Significant-Other-to-Appreciate-You-More-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn31@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-18-020_1e7ac38d9e3f6a67.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380966},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Be Organized in School","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>It can be really frustrating to feel like you're always forgetting your homework or losing your pencils, but you might not realize how much it's affecting your school performance. Fortunately, those problems can usually be fixed by a little organization. When you keep your work area, schedule, and even class notes organized, you'll almost certainly find that it's easier to keep up with your schoolwork, and you might even see an improvement in your grades! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Assignments\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Assignments\">Assignments</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Create a binder with a separate section for each class. Even if you do a lot of your schoolwork online, you'll still have things like worksheets and handouts to keep track of. To keep all of your paperwork organized, use a 3-ring binder, and use dividers so there's one section for every class you're taking.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-1-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 1 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-1-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-1-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try putting color-coded pocket folders inside the binder to keep track of papers that don't have holes punched in them. For instance, you might use a blue divider, folder, and notebook for math.</li> \n    <li>Any time you get a piece of paper for class, put it in your binder right away. That will help keep you from having a lot of loose, crinkled paper to sort through at the end of each day.</li> \n    <li>Figure out the organization method that works for you—you might want to have a section in your binder for graded papers and one for assignments that are ready to turn in, for instance.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Organize your digital files into folders. Just like you need to organize your physical papers for class, it's also important to keep your digital files sorted. Any time you save a document, whether it's a draft of a paper or a worksheet that you downloaded, make sure to save it to a folder for that specific class. You can even use sub-folders to separate different types of files for a single class.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-2-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 2 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-2-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-2-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, you might have a parent folder labeled \"Biology,\" then within that folder, you might include sub-folders like, \"Class Notes\" \"Homework,\" \"Research Paper,\" and \"Handouts.\"</li> \n    <li>Consider using a service like Google Drive or iCloud to store your files online (or on the cloud). That way, you won't lose your files if your computer crashes.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Track all of your assignments in a planner to keep up with them. Keep a weekly planner so you don't forget to turn in any important assignments. Check your planner every day, and write down any homework, tests, or other important dates as soon as you learn about them. <sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-3-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 3 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-3-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-3-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your notebooks and folders are color-coded, consider using the same color pens to write down your assignments. For instance, you might write all of your math assignments in blue and all of your English assignments in red.</li> \n    <li>Include other activities in your planner as well. That way, it will be easy for you to see which days you'll be busiest, so you'll know how to plan your studying for each week.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use an online planner if you prefer to keep up with things digitally. You can use the calendar app on your phone, tablet, or computer to keep up with assignments.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> For instance, you might track everything in Google Calendar. You could also use apps like myHomework Student Planner, Trello, or Power Planner to help you manage assignments and to-do lists.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-4-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 4 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-4-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-4-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your school might provide an online assignment manager that you can use, as well.</li> \n    <li>When you're trying to decide between a paper or digital planner, think about which one you're likely to check the most often. For instance, if you already have a paper planner but you forget to look at it most days, you might do better with an app you can put on your phone.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Set alarms in your phone to help you remember important deadlines. Even if you're using a paper or digital planner, sometimes a due date might still creep up on you without you realizing it. If there's anything really important you need to remember, set an alarm in your phone. Try to set it a little ahead of the actual deadline so you'll be reminded in time if you do forget.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-5-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 5 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-5-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-5-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if you have a big paper due for Lit class, you might set a reminder for 1 week before the due date so you won't forget to work on your final draft, as well as a reminder for the morning it's due so you don't forget to bring it to class.</li> \n    <li>Your online planner may be able to notify you about your assignments, so check out the settings!</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Notes\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Notes\">Notes</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Start a new page of notes at the start of each class. Every day when you start class, take out a fresh sheet of paper. Write the date and the class at the top of the page, then set it aside while you listen to the teacher. Throughout the class, use that sheet to write down the important points your teacher mentions.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-6-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 6 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-6-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-6-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your teacher mentions a new assignment, write the due date in your planner immediately.</li> \n    <li>Writing the date on your paper will help you keep your notes organized, and it can be helpful if you're trying to recall something specific while you're studying.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Jot down the important things your teacher talks about. Keep your notes simple and effective by writing down keywords and short sentences from the lesson. Don't try to write down everything your teacher says—just write down the main concepts, preferably in your own words.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-7-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 7 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-7-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-7-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try using a highlighter to call attention to anything you think is especially important.</li> \n    <li>If your teacher mentions that something will be on the test, be especially sure to write it down. <sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Rewriting things in your own words may help you learn, understand, and memorize the material better!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try the <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Take-Cornell-Notes\" title=\"Take Cornell Notes\">Cornell method</a> for more organized notes. To follow the Cornell method, draw a horizontal line about 6 lines from the bottom of your lined paper. Then, draw a vertical line about from the left side of the paper. This should create a total of 3 boxes. Use the left-hand vertical box to take down key points, and the right-hand larger box to take down general notes. After class, use the bottom horizontal box for review, clarification, and summary.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-8-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 8 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-8-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-8-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you're studying for a test, first read the bottom horizontal box, and then go up to the other 2 boxes if you need more information.</li> \n    <li>The Cornell note-taking method might be the right note-taking method for you if you're studying something like History that has a lot of key points and specific details.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Practice the <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Mind-Map\" title=\"Make a Mind Map\">Mind Map note taking</a> format. For Mind Mapping, you'll need a blank sheet of paper instead of lined paper. Mind Mapping uses bubbles to connect individual keywords to one another. The benefits of Mind Map note-taking is that you can easily see the relationship and connections between 2 ideas at a glance.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-9-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 9 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-9-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-9-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you feel yourself often getting bored taking notes, try Mind Mapping, since it's more creative!</li> \n    <li>Mind Mapping can be effective for subjects like Literature, where 1 main subject (i.e. a book) has several important features (i.e. characters, themes, plot points, etc).</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Studying and Time Management\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Studying-and-Time-Management\">Studying and Time Management</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Do your homework at the same time every day. Just like it's easier to get up in the morning when you wake up at the same time every day, it's easier to remember to study and do your homework if you have a set time for it. It might feel a little strange to have a set schedule at first, but if you stick to it for a few weeks, you'll find that it starts to come naturally.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-10-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 10 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-10-Version-6.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-10-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>As you're planning your schedule, think about when you tend to be most productive—are you full of energy after school, or do you prefer to have a little downtime when you get home, then do your homework after dinner?</li> \n    <li>If you're learning remotely, think about the times of day you tend to work best, and plan your difficult subjects for that time period. Save your easiest subjects for times where you might tend to drag a little more.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Study in a quiet, distraction-free spot. Whether you're doing your homework after school or primarily learning online, you'll need a quiet, calm spot at home where you can focus on your schoolwork. Try to pick a spot that's out of the way, like a desk in your room. However, if that's not an option, let your family members know when you'll need some peace and quiet so they don't bother you while you're working.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-11-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 11 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-11-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-11-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It's a good idea to turn off notifications on your phone and tablet during your study time. That way, you won't be distracted by text messages or social media mentions.</li> \n    <li>Some people study best in complete silence, but other people do better with a little background music or white noise. Experiment to find what works for you.</li> \n    <li>If you start getting distracted while you're studying, get up and take a 10-15 minute break, then come back to your work.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Work on large assignments a little at a time. Don't let big projects pile up on you—you'll feel anxious and rushed if you wait until the last minute, and your grade will likely suffer. Instead, start working on things like essays and art projects as soon as you know they're due. Break the project down into smaller, more manageable parts, and tackle a little at a time until the job is done.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-12-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 12 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-12-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-12-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if you have to write a 3-page paper in a week, you might schedule one day for doing research, one for filling out a detailed outline, one for writing a first draft, and two days for revisions. That will still leave you a couple of days of free time in case you fall behind or have other things you need to work on.</li> \n    <li>Working a little bit each day on your project will help the workload feel smaller. It will also give you more time to relax at the end of the day.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Review your notes from class every day. Even if you're busy working on homework and other projects, take a few minutes of your study time each day to go over the notes you took in class. That will help you retain what you learned, and it's a lot easier to study for a test a little at a time instead of trying to cram all at once.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-13-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 13 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-13-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-13-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is a good time to rewrite your notes if they're a little messy.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Get ready for the next day every night. Before you go to bed, check your planner and make sure you have all of the assignments and supplies for the next day of school. Put them in your backpack if you'll be taking them to school, and consider packing your lunch at night so you won't be rushed the next morning.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-14-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 14 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-14-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-14-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can even lay out your outfit for the next day! That way, all you'll have to worry about in the morning is getting up, brushing your teeth, and eating breakfast.</li> \n    <li>If there's anything important you need to remember for the next day, try putting a sticky note somewhere you'll be sure to see it, like on your bathroom mirror, lunchbox, or door.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Supplies and Study Space\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Supplies-and-Study-Space\">Supplies and Study Space</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Keep your school supplies in one place. If you're attending school in-person, use your backpack and locker to store your items, or keep them in your desk or stacked in a bin if you're learning remotely. In addition, use pencil cases or pouches to organize small things like pens, pencils, highlighters, glue, scissors, and calculators.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-15-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 15 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-15-Version-6.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-15-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>There is no “right” or “wrong” way to organize your supplies—the important thing is that you consistently put your things in the same place so you'll always know where they are.</li> \n    <li>Try keeping your pens, pencils, and colored pencils in a pencil case, for instance, and keep your extra papers and notebooks in a desk drawer at home.</li> \n    <li>Even if you want to rush out of class when the bell rings, it will be a lot easier to find your stuff later if you take a few seconds to put everything away neatly.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stock up any time you're running low on school supplies. A big part of being organized is being prepared. If you're running out of paper, pencils, or something else, make sure to buy more or ask your parents to buy you more. Put it in your pencil case or backpack as soon as you get it, so you don't forget it at home!<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-16-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 16 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-16-Version-6.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-16-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Being unprepared for class can not only distract you, but your classmates as well, especially if you have to ask them for supplies. It can also detract from your participation grade.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Throw away anything you no longer need at the end of each day. Every day, take a few minutes to look through your school belongings, including your study area, backpack, locker, and binder. Toss out things like scrap paper, candy wrappers, dried-up pens, or anything else that's definitely trash. Keeping your study area tidy will make it easier to concentrate on your schoolwork.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized-in-School#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-Organized-in-School-Step-17-Version-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be Organized in School Step 17 Version 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Be-Organized-in-School-Step-17-Version-7.jpg/aid83324-v4-728px-Be-Organized-in-School-Step-17-Version-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don't throw away old assignments and tests, even after they're graded—they might be helpful when you're trying to study for final exams.</li> \n    <li>If you study in an area that's also used for other things, like your family's dining table, try keeping your papers and books stacked in a bin when you're not using them.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don't expect to become organized overnight! It takes time, so be patient with yourself and have confidence that it'll work out soon.</li> \n  <li>You should clean out your backpack at least once a week or after school everyday to get rid of trash or rubbish that you don't need in there.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Pencil case</li> \n  <li>Binders</li> \n  <li>Pencils</li> \n  <li>Pens</li> \n  <li>Notebooks</li> \n  <li>Paper</li> \n  <li>Highlighters</li> \n  <li>Planner</li> \n  <li>Sticky notes</li> \n  <li>Organization tools (storage bins, pencil holders, etc.)</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-Organized-in-School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Organized\" title=\"Be Organized\">Be Organized</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\"
