\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Oct 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"72ba321f1ea70dbce52bee4936911bf0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn13@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-819_ea35d344b73082a7.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":35775,"destBytes":21444,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn13@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-01-819_ea35d344b73082a7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn16@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-27-995_1286526f5732259c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn38@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-24-092_f91653d537015623.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn16@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-23-046_fa715b0f10a3d1c1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn22@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-28-688_af4907628527142b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn19@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-27-145_c1a32855dcdc94a7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/84/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn29@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-25-647_1e1dc9ca4fac6ec2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn88@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-24-593_f4243248367f51d7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn91@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-19-409_2251a7a7b2aad574.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid10785237-v4-728px-Stop-Your-Nails-from-Peeling-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn67@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-26-787_7ba7663e2d262e98.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380883},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>You might not realize just how much you use your shoulders until you injure the group of muscles and tendons that surround your shoulder joint called your rotator cuff. Whether you’re exercising, playing sports, or trying to reach into the backseat behind you, a strained or tight rotator cuff can make things super painful and difficult. If the injury is serious enough, you may have difficulty raising your arm and might even have to get surgery. The good news is you can use a resistance band to help stretch and strengthen your rotator cuff. But, before you do, check with your doctor to make sure these exercises and stretches are safe for you and won’t cause further injury. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Rotations\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Rotations\">Rotations</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Make a loop with the band and tie it to a doorknob. Take a resistance band designed for exercise and form it into a loop. Tie the ends together securely so it won’t come undone.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> Find a doorknob or a stable object such as a table or desk and loop the exercise band around it so it’s firmly attached.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure the ends are tied together really well so there’s no chance they separate while you’re stretching.</li> \n    <li>You can also use a band that already is a loop.</li> \n    <li>Use an object that’s about the height of your hip.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Target your rotator cuff with internal rotations. Stand with the shoulder you want to stretch facing the doorknob and take the end of the band with 1 hand. Hold your arm at your side with your elbow bent 90 degrees. Slowly bring your arm across your body, which will cause your shoulder to rotate internally. Then, slowly return to the starting position.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure you keep your elbow close to your side to help target your rotator cuff.</li> \n    <li>Aim for 10-15 reps on each arm.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Follow up with external rotations to balance your stretch. Stand with the shoulder you want to stretch away from the doorknob and hold the band with your arm at your side and your elbow bent at a 90-degree angle. Slowly move your arm outward to externally rotate the inside of your shoulder. Then, slowly bring your arm back to the starting position.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Just like with the internal rotations, it’s super important that you keep your elbow close to your side so the exercise is focused on your rotator cuff.</li> \n    <li>Do the rotations on both arms and aim for about 10-15 reps to stretch your rotator cuff.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try upward rotations to stretch your cuff further. Stand facing the doorknob and take hold of the end of the band. Bend your elbow to a 90-degree angle and raise your arm to shoulder-height. Keep your elbow level and slowly raise your hand until it’s in line with your head to rotate your shoulder and stretch the cuff. Then, slowly return to the start position.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure you stretch both shoulders.</li> \n    <li>Try a few reps at first and try to progress to 3 sets of 12 reps on each arm.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Work your back and shoulders with standing rows. Stand facing the doorknob and take the band in 1 hand. Hold the band at your side with your elbow bent at a 90-degree angle. Slowly pull your elbow straight back and then slowly return to the start position. Perform 1 set on 1 arm, then switch and do it on your other arm.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Aim for 3 sets of 12 reps to get a good stretch of your rotator cuff and upper back.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Retraction\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Retraction\">Retraction</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Put the band around a bedpost at waist height. Take an elastic exercise band and place it around a solid object like a bedpost. Line up the band so it’s even with your waist.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use an elastic band designed for exercise such as surgical tubing or a Thera-Band.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hold each end of the band with your hands. Center the band on the solid object so both sides are the same length. Grip 1 end of the band with 1 hand and the other end with your other hand.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Take a firm grip so the band doesn’t pop out of your hand while you’re using it.</li> \n    <li>It may help to loop the ends of the band around your hands so you have a better grip.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Bend your elbows 90 degrees and pull the band back. Keep your arms at your sides and bend your elbows to 90 degrees. Slowly pull the band back toward your hips to stretch your rotator cuff inside both of your shoulders.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Move slowly and carefully. Don’t yank or snap back on the band.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Squeeze your shoulder blades and return to the starting position. As you pull the band back, squeeze your shoulder blades together to deepen the stretch. When you can’t stretch anymore, slowly release the tension and move your arms back to their original position.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Repeat the exercise 8-12 times to get a good scapular retraction, which is also a great way to stretch your rotator cuff.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Safety\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Safety\">Safety</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Warm up with 5-10 minutes of low-impact activity before you stretch. Get your muscles and joints ready to be stretched with some light warmup activities such as walking or riding a stationary bike. Spend at least 5 minutes getting your blood pumping and your body primed for the stretching exercises.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Stretching without first warming up could lead to another injury.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stop exercising and call your doctor if you feel pain. If you’re not sure if you’re performing the exercises correctly, stop doing them to prevent possibly injuring yourself. If you feel pain or you injure your shoulder while you’re doing the exercises, stop doing them and call your doctor to be safe.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-11.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Some clicking and popping during the exercises doesn’t necessarily mean something is wrong as long as there’s no pain. But if you feel like your rotator cuff is grinding, there could be a problem and you need to talk to your doctor.</li> \n    <li>A little soreness after stretching is normal. But if it doesn’t go away after 2 hours, see your doctor.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wait 3-6 weeks after you’ve had shoulder surgery to stretch. Stretching your rotator cuff can be really beneficial, but if you recently had shoulder surgery, it’s important that you wait until you’ve healed enough to safely perform the exercises. Wait at least 6-8 weeks, and follow the advice of your doctor to avoid seriously injuring yourself.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Your Rotator Cuff with a Band Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you had surgery for tendinitis, your doctor may recommend that you start stretching your rotator cuff right away.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Start slow and take it easy if you’re just starting to stretch your rotator cuff. You don’t want to strain or further injure yourself.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Talk to your doctor before you try stretching your rotator cuff with a band, especially if you recently had shoulder surgery to make sure it’s safe for you.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"ce825421b615fd7880e61a4a028caf81","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn50@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-01-806_a71b5e6fc0c5290b.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":25070,"destBytes":14838,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn50@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-01-806_a71b5e6fc0c5290b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn31@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-20-326_ad8eb6ffb36e14ab.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn7@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-20-529_0e367b3e49acd255.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn39@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-19-225_230416ba66df200a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn59@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-17-959_d300a2800f969e3f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn92@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-19-003_89f2690b7de30368.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn22@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-24-618_00890ab6bb4c7eb1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn41@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-28-097_a528b257835d811b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-19-455_f008a9675a7f4d2a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn46@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-28-857_e0943a58e333e8d9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-11.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-20-314_107bb2cbf4afc6e4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid12156360-v4-728px-Stretch-Your-Rotator-Cuff-with-a-Band-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn87@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-20-423_cb375589de4e8aac.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380934},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Cover Furniture with Wallpaper","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Adding some wallpaper to surfaces can give new life to an old set of drawers, a night stand, a desk, or pretty much any other piece of furniture you want to rejuvenate or update to match your decor. This custom update doesn’t take a lot of materials or time to do. Depending on the size of the furniture you want to cover with wallpaper and how many surfaces you actually want to cover, you can probably get the job done on a rainy Saturday afternoon and have your furniture ready to use by Sunday morning! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Prep Work\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Prep-Work\">Prep Work</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Wipe down the piece of furniture using a damp sponge. Get a clean sponge wet and wring out the excess water. Use it to clean off the piece of furniture you want to cover with wallpaper, paying special attention to the surfaces you plan to actually stick wallpaper onto. Wait for the furniture to air dry.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-1.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Any dirt or grit on the surfaces of your furniture interferes with the wallpaper’s adherence and can ruin a smooth finish, so that’s why it’s important to clean off the furniture first.</li> \n    <li>There’s no limit to the types of furniture you can update with wallpaper. Try wallpapering bookshelves, night stands, dressers, cabinets, coffee tables, and anything else you think is in need of a new look!</li> \n    <li>Note that you can wallpaper furniture made out of pretty much any material. However, if you want to stick wallpaper to glass, you must use peel-and-stick wallpaper because traditional wallpaper and glue won’t stick well to glass. Wood is the best surface for using regular wallpaper and glue on.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove any drawers and doors from the piece. Pull out drawers that you want to cover in wallpaper or that may get in the way of you covering other surfaces. Unscrew any doors and take them off their hinges if you want to cover them or if they’re in the way as well.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-2.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you could take all the drawers out of your old, dingy dresser and cover the front of each drawer with a fun, brightly-colored, patterned wallpaper. You could also cover the top of the dresser with the same wallpaper to make it match.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take off any hardware that’s in the way where you want to add wallpaper. Unscrew and remove handles from any drawers and doors you’re planning to cover in wallpaper. Unscrew and remove other hardware, such as hinges, if it is in the way of surfaces you’re covering with wallpaper.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-3.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you’re covering the door of a kitchen sideboard in wallpaper, take the handle off the door. If you’re going to cover the outside or inside of the cabinet as well, remove the hinges from the sideboard so they don’t get in the way.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Wallpaper\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Wallpaper\">Wallpaper</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Place the wallpaper over a surface and crease it over the surface’s edges. Line up a piece of wallpaper on top of the surface you want to stick it to. Fold over the edges and use your fingers to firmly crease the wallpaper where you fold it to make your cut lines.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-4.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want to cover the edges of a surface as well, just fold the wallpaper over and under the edge and make 2 crease lines. The second crease is your cut line.</li> \n    <li>You can use either peel-and-stick wallpaper or regular wallpaper to cover your furniture.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut the wallpaper where you creased it using a craft knife and a piece of cardboard. Place the piece of wallpaper print-side-down on a piece of cardboard. Slice very carefully straight along the creases you made using a sharp craft knife.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-5.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also use a utility knife or box cutter instead of a craft knife.</li> \n    <li>You can use a cutting mat instead of cardboard if you have one..</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Peel the backing off or apply a coat of Mod Podge to the back of the wallpaper. Just pull the backing off the adhesive side of the wallpaper if you’re using peel-and-stick wallpaper. Use a sponge brush to apply a thin coat of Mod Podge to the backside of the wallpaper if you’re using regular wallpaper.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-6.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re using Mod Podge to stick regular wallpaper to your piece of furniture, you could also apply a thin coat of glue to the surface you’re covering instead of to the back of the wallpaper.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Line the wallpaper up over the surface and press it onto the surface. Carefully position the wallpaper where you want to stick it. Press it down firmly against the surface when you’re sure it’s oriented correctly and smooth it out using your hands.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-7.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re wrapping wallpaper around the edges of a surface, the corners can be tricky. Use your craft knife to carefully make a horizontal cut in the wallpaper, parallel to the edge of the surface, in each corner. Fold the flap you create neatly over the edge at the corner.</li> \n    <li>If you’re covering multiple surfaces next to one another, such as several consecutive drawers, use consecutive smaller pieces of wallpaper from the larger roll so the wallpaper’s pattern lines up from one drawer to the next.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Run a brayer along the paper from one end to the other to smooth out bubbles. A brayer is a small hand roller made of rubber or another similar material that is typically used to apply ink in printing. Start at one end of the surface you just covered in wallpaper and roll a brayer firmly along the wallpaper all the way to the other end to smooth out the wallpaper. Go back to the side you started from and repeat the process, working your way down the surface and from side to side, until you get rid of all the bubbles.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-8.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t have a brayer, you could use something with a hard flat edge, such as a plastic ruler or a plastic putty knife, to smooth out the wallpaper.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Reassembly\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reassembly\">Reassembly</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Let the wallpaper dry overnight before you do reassembly if you used glue. Leave the piece of furniture disassembled if you covered it in regular wallpaper using Mod Podge to stick it on. This allows the glue plenty of time to cure.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1b/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-9.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you try to put your furniture back together right away, you might accidentally unstick some of the wallpaper, so it’s best to let the glue cure all the way.</li> \n    <li>This isn’t necessary if you used peel-and-stick wallpaper.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Reattach all the hardware you removed. Screw handles back into drawers and doors. Put any hinges and other hardware you removed back on as well.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-10.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can just use all the old hardware or you can replace the hardware with different varieties that go with the new wallpaper you applied to your furniture if you want to.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Screw doors back onto the furniture and replace all the drawers. Put any doors you removed back on the hinges. Slide any drawers back into the slots they belong in.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Furniture with Wallpaper Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-11.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep in mind that wallpaper can get damaged by heat and liquids, so exercise caution if you’re using the surface you covered in wallpaper to set things like mugs on. You can use coasters or even get a piece of glass or plexiglass cut to set on top of the wallpaper and protect it.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you don’t want to worry about matching wallpaper patterns between consecutive drawers and the like, choose a wallpaper that has an allover print that doesn’t require close matching to look great.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Be careful when you’re using a sharp craft knife to cut wallpaper. Keep your fingers and hands away from the cut line and don’t cut on top of any surfaces that you don’t want to damage.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Piece of furniture</li> \n  <li>Sponge</li> \n  <li>Water</li> \n  <li>Screwdriver</li> \n  <li>Craft knife</li> \n  <li>Cardboard</li> \n  <li>Wallpaper</li> \n  <li>Mod Podge</li> \n  <li>Sponge brush</li> \n  <li>Brayer</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PRfZRYU9JYk&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=25\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PRfZRYU9JYk&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=25</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a \n   <li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://modpodgerocksblog.com/vintage-wallpaper-magnetic-chalkboard/\">https://modpodgerocksblog.com/vintage-wallpaper-magnetic-chalkboard/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.redbookmag.com/home/decor/how-to/g426/decorate-an-old-dresser/?slide=8\">https://www.redbookmag.com/home/decor/how-to/g426/decorate-an-old-dresser/?slide=8</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.redbookmag.com/home/decor/how-to/g426/decorate-an-old-dresser/?slide=9\">https://www.redbookmag.com/home/decor/how-to/g426/decorate-an-old-dresser/?slide=9</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 03 Oct 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-1.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"aba39ce87349df846d72feea3349fb93","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn26@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-01-804_8114b56521715c7f.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":46614,"destBytes":15452,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-1.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn26@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-01-804_8114b56521715c7f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-2.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn80@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-26-853_4b17880293c35a59.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-3.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn9@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-26-197_571501dbd4844915.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-4.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn51@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-22-275_076abd88100ed5f4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-5.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn93@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-18-074_e002a663e1d0addd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-6.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-19-079_713dfa0884643ada.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-7.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn24@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-20-020_d1ff4d35231d6c08.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-8.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn55@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-19-408_7853d6b8f2634229.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1b/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-9.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn60@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-27-682_7b86a1309e5b9942.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-10.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn68@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-19-317_941d06d0ade0ba63.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-11.jpg/aid12166182-v4-728px-Cover-Furniture-with-Wallpaper-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn95@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-24-563_1eb2083798efecef.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214380937},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:00","title":"How to Make a Foot Scrub","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Have you ever wanted to treat yourself to a refreshing foot scrub, but didn't like how expensive some of the scrubs were in the store? Making your own foot scrub can sound like a lot of work, but most of them involve 2 to 3 ingredients and a little bit of stirring. You can pick out which foot scrub sounds the most refreshing to you, or you can make a couple different kinds to give out as gifts to your friends and family. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Peppermint Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Peppermint-Foot-Scrub\">Peppermint Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>1 cup (201 g) of sea salt</li> \n  <li>of olive oil or coconut oil</li> \n  <li>1 to 2 drops of peppermint essential oil</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Lemon Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Lemon-Foot-Scrub\">Lemon Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>2 cups (400 g) of granulated sugar</li> \n  <li>of almond oil or coconut oil</li> \n  <li>10 to 20 drops of lemon essential oil</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Coffee Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Coffee-Foot-Scrub\">Coffee Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>1/4 cup (32 g) of coffee grounds</li> \n  <li>of olive oil or coconut oil</li> \n  <li>1.5 tbsp (22.5 g) of cinnamon</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Brown Sugar Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Brown-Sugar-Foot-Scrub\">Brown Sugar Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>1/2 cup (64 g) of brown sugar</li> \n  <li>of canola oil</li> \n  <li>of vanilla extract or lemon juice</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Peppermint Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Peppermint-Foot-Scrub_2\">Peppermint Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pour 1 cup (201 g) of sea salt into a bowl. In this scrub, salt is the main ingredient. Grab a bowl that’s large enough to hold all your ingredients, then pour in 1 cup (201 g) of sea salt. If there’s any lumps, go in with a fork and sift them out before you add your next ingredients.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also use pink Himalayan salt instead of sea salt for a cute, pink color.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add in of olive oil or coconut oil. The carrier oil is an unscented oil that will bind all of your ingredients together. Add in this oil to your sugar, then use a wooden spoon to stir it all together.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re using coconut oil, melt it in the microwave before you add it to your scrub.</li> \n    <li>As you mix, you’ll notice your scrub getting thick and paste-like.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drop in 3 drops of peppermint essential oil. Use the dropper on your bottle of essential oils to carefully add 3 drops of peppermint. Stir the peppermint in evenly with your wooden spoon to spread it throughout the foot scrub.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Peppermint essential oil is very strong, which is why you only need a little bit.</li> \n    <li>Never use essential oils without diluting them first, as they can cause skin irritation in concentrated quantities.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use this scrub for a refreshing exfoliant. Spread about 1 tbsp (14 g) of the foot scrub onto your feet and up your legs slightly. Massage it into your skin, then let it sit for 5 to 10 minutes before rinsing it off with cool water. When you use it, you’ll feel a slight cooling sensation from the peppermint that will refresh and rejuvenate your skin. It’s great for a pick me up after you’ve worked out or walked a lot during the day.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have any open sores on your feet, the peppermint might make them sting. Use caution.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Store the foot scrub in an airtight container. If you have any scrub left over, seal it in a glass jar with a lid. You can store the scrub in a cool, dry place, like your kitchen cabinet or pantry. Try to use your scrub as soon as possible so the oil doesn’t break down.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Depending on which oil you used, the ingredients may start to break down after a few weeks or a few months. Try to use your foot scrub right away so the ingredients stay fresh.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Lemon Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Lemon-Foot-Scrub_2\">Lemon Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Add 2 cups (400 g) of granulated sugar to a bowl. Grab a large bowl and pour in your granulated sugar. If you see any lumps, use a fork or a whisk to smooth them out before you add your next ingredients.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Sugar is a great natural exfoliant since it’s slightly coarse.</li> \n    <li>For a lemon salt scrub, use sea salt instead of sugar.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mix in of almond oil or coconut oil. Your carrier oil will spread throughout your foot scrub and bind all of the ingredients together. Add in your almond oil or liquid coconut oil, then stir your mixture together with a wooden spoon.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also use olive oil or canola oil from your kitchen.</li> \n    <li>To make your scrub yellow colored to match the theme, add in mustard oil instead.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add in 10 to 20 drops of lemon essential oil. Grab a bottle of lemon essential oil and use the dropper on the lid. Add in 10 to 20 drops of lemon essential oil, then stir the mixture to spread the lemon scent out evenly.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Lemon is a refreshing citrus scent that will perk up your skin and soothe it at the same time.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try this scrub to refresh your feet with a citrus zest. Wet your feet and scoop up about 1 tbsp (14 g) of the scrub. Rub it onto your feet and legs, focusing on any dry, cracked parts. Let your feet soak in the scrub for 5 to 10 minutes, then rinse it off with cool water.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Citrus is a light scent that’s mildly refreshing. It’s great for starting your day with a refresher or treating yourself after a hike.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep your foot scrub in an airtight container. For your leftover foot scrub, store it in a glass jar with a lid. Write the date that you made the scrub on the jar, then store it in a cool, dry place. Try to use your scrub as soon as you can for the most benefit.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also give your foot scrub out as gifts! Decorate the jar with a fun ribbon or a piece of twine to make it special.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Coffee Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Coffee-Foot-Scrub_2\">Coffee Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Spoon about 1/4 cup (32 g) of coffee grounds into a bowl. Take your old coffee grounds from when you made coffee earlier and spoon them into a large bowl. It’s okay if they’re a little wet, since that will help bind your mixture together.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Coffee grounds have caffeine in them, which can actually help to “wake up,” or brighten, your skin.</li> \n    <li>To make this even more exfoliating, add in the same amount of granulated or brown sugar with your coffee grounds.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add in of olive oil or coconut oil. Pour in olive oil or liquid coconut oil to your mixture, then use your spoon to combine all of your ingredients. The mixture will start to form a thick paste that’s easy to spread with your spoon.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Since coffee grounds are already a little sticky, you don’t need as much oil.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mix in 1.5 tbsp (22.5 g) of cinnamon. Take a spoonful of cinnamon and pour it into your coffee ground mixture. Use a wooden spoon to mix up the ingredients until they form a thick paste that smells great!<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cinnamon is slightly spicy, so it will help to bring blood flow to the area and wake up your skin even more.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use this scrub to wake up your skin. Since coffee has caffeine in it, it can actually bring blood flow to your feet and “wake up,” or refresh, your skin. You can use this any time you feel like your feet need a little pick me up, or you can use it as an exfoliant to get the dead skin off your toes.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Coffee grounds also smell delicious, so they’ll scent your skin, too!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Store the mixture in an airtight container. If you don’t want to use your coffee scrub right away, pour it into a glass jar and seal it with a lid. Try to use your foot scrub as soon as you can to get the most benefit out of your ingredients.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The sooner you use your scrub, the fresher it will be.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Brown Sugar Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Brown-Sugar-Foot-Scrub_2\">Brown Sugar Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mix 1/2 cup (64 g) of brown sugar with of canola oil. In a large bowl, pour your brown sugar and canola oil together. Use a wooden spoon to mix up your ingredients until they form a lumpy paste that’s easy to spread.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Brown sugar is mildly exfoliating, but it also smells great.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add in of vanilla extract. To give your foot scrub a delicious scent, pour in about of pure vanilla extract. Then, use a wooden spoon to mix it into your ingredients until they form a thick paste.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For a fresher citrus scent, add in of lemon juice instead.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use this scrub for a naturally scented exfoliant. Brown sugar is a mild exfoliant, and the natural scent of the vanilla or lemon juice is a great way to scent your skin without using a concentrate. You can try out this foot scrub anytime your feet feel dry or cracked to give them a refresh and start again.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-18.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try using this scrub during the holidays when sugar and spices are prevalent.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Store the scrub in an airtight container. If you have any left over, put it into an airtight glass jar with a lid. Try to use your scrub as soon as possible so your ingredients stay fresh.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Foot-Scrub#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Foot Scrub Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-19.jpg/aid688887-v4-728px-Make-a-Foot-Scrub-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your scrub won’t go bad, but the ingredients won’t stay fresh for long.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Try keeping a few jars of foot scrub in your home so you can grab them whenever you need a little bit of TLC.</li> \n  <li>Foot scrubs make great gifts, especially around the holidays.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14\" title=\"Edit section: Peppermint Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Peppermint-Foot-Scrub_3\">Peppermint Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Bowl</li> \n  <li>Wooden spoon</li> \n  <li>Glass jar</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Foot-Scrub&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15\" title=\"Edit section: Lemon Foot Scrub\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Lemon-Foot-Scrub_3\">Lemon Foot Scrub</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Bowl</li> \n  <li>Wooden spoon</li> \n  <li>Glass jar</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" jar</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\"
